questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 1:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'the land of Canaan' (v1) and the repeated use of 'the land' (v3, v7, v9, v11).
tips: Notice the phrase 'the land of Canaan' appears in verse 1
Pay attention to the description of the plain (v7) with iron chariots
Notice the pattern of forced labor (v11-22) as a key compromise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Judah and the tribes of Israel) does WHAT (conquest of Canaan), WHERE (the land of Canaan), and WHY (to drive out the Canaanites but only partially succeeded).
tips: Include that Judah captured Jerusalem and Hebron (v3-4)
Note that Caleb's nephew Othniel captured Debir (v5-6)
Describe the failure in the plain (iron chariots) and the Jebusites (v7-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plain with iron chariots (v7), the Jebusites in Benjamin (v9), or the forced labor pattern (v11-22).
tips: The plain with iron chariots shows a specific military failure that the Israelites couldn't overcome
The Jebusites in Benjamin (a distinct group) remained, indicating that even in the hill country, the conquest was incomplete
The forced labor pattern (v11-22) reveals a compromise that the Israelites made, which led to long-term problems in the land

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about the incomplete conquest of Canaan?
tips: The passage warns that the Israelites' incomplete conquest was due to their lack of full obedience to God's commands
This incomplete conquest led to the Israelites being under the influence of Canaanite practices (forced labor)
The author's purpose is to show that the land of Canaan is not fully under God's covenant until the Israelites drive out all the Canaanites

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The pattern of forced labor, the meaning of 'the plain', and why the tribes each had incomplete conquests?
tips: The phrase 'forced labor' (v11-22) means the Israelites put the Canaanites to work in their fields instead of driving them out, which is a compromise that led to the land being mixed with Canaanite cu
'The plain' (v7) refers to a vulnerable region of land that was easily attacked by iron chariots (a military technology of the time)
The tribes each had incomplete conquests because they were independent in their efforts, and the passage lists each tribe that failed to dispossess a specific group

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In your current situation, where have you allowed the 'Canaanite' elements (things that are not part of God's kingdom) to remain in your life without fully driving them out? How can you practice the pattern of complete obedience (like driving out the Canaanites) this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience (e.g., the 'plain' where you can't drive out the Canaanites)
Think about something that is causing you to be in a state of compromise (forced labor) rather than complete obedience
Take steps to 'drive out' the Canaanite elements by surrendering them to God (e.g., confessing sin, seeking God's help)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of incomplete conquest and the need for complete obedience.
tips: Thank God for His provision in the past and ask for the strength to complete the work now
Pray for the courage to drive out the Canaanites (sinful habits) in your life
Ask God to help you avoid the compromise of forced labor (i.e., allowing sin to remain in your life)

chapters.chapterTitle: The Angel at Bochim; The Cycle Begins

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 2:1-23 aloud, focusing on the angel's rebuke in verses 1-12 and the weeping at Bochim.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I brought you up from Egypt, swore to give this land' (v.7)
Pay attention to the name 'Bochim' meaning 'weeping' (v.11-12)
Identify the cycle description in verses 19-23

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is rebuked, WHAT the angel says, WHERE it happens (Bochim), and WHY this rebuke occurs (Israel's disobedience to God's covenant).
tips: Include the three key events: the angel's rebuke, the weeping at Bochim, and the death of the generation that knew the LORD
Note that Israel had abandoned God for the Baals (v.13-14)
Describe how the cycle of sin and judgment begins (v.19-23)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the angel's direct rebuke (v.1-12), the weeping at Bochim (v.11-12), or the cycle description (v.19-23).
tips: The angel's rebuke is personal and historical: 'I brought you up from Egypt' shows God's faithfulness to Israel
The weeping at Bochim (Bochim = 'weeping') illustrates the emotional impact of sin and the consequences
The cycle description (v.19-23) is a powerful template for the entire book of Judges, showing how sin leads to oppression and then deliverance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/editors) trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: The author warns that if Israel continues in idolatry, they will face oppression and the cycle of judges will begin
This passage sets the stage for the book of Judges by showing the consequences of sin and the recurring pattern of deliverance
Theologically, it emphasizes that God's covenant with Israel is conditional on obedience

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The angel's origin (Gilgal), the meaning of 'thorns', and the cycle of judges.
tips: Gilgal was a place of early Israelite worship and the tabernacle, so the angel coming from there shows a connection to the past
'Thorns' (Hebrew: 'shar') refers to a burden or obstacle, not a blessing (v.11)
The cycle of judges (v.19-23) begins when the generation that knew the LORD dies, and the next generation sins and then God sends a judge

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you break the cycle of sin and oppression this week? Reflect on a situation where you've been in a pattern of sin and how God's deliverance might come through you or others.
tips: Identify one area of sin in your life that you need to repent and seek God's help
Ask for the courage to cry out to God when you feel oppressed
Pray for a community of believers who will remember God and not fall into idolatry

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His faithfulness in the past and ask for His help to break the cycle of sin.
tips: Thank God that He has delivered Israel from Egypt and continues to be faithful
Pray for the courage to avoid idolatry and to seek God's help when you are in sin
Ask God to send a deliverer (judge) for your current situation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 3:1-30 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the oppression and deliverance.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Israel' (v.1, v.4, v.7) to emphasize their identity and vulnerability
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the oppression: 'cushan-rishathaim' (a Mesopotamian king) and the 8-year oppression (v.2-3)
The phrase 'the Spirit of the LORD came upon Othniel' (v.4) is a key moment of divine empowerment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is oppressed, WHAT God does, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Israel's sin leads to oppression.
tips: Include the 8-year oppression by Cushan-rishathaim and Othniel's 40-year deliverance
Note the 18-year oppression by Eglon of Moab and Ehud's assassination
Mention Shamgar's brief but significant victory over 600 Philistines

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Othniel's deliverance (v.4), Ehud's left-handed assassination (v.14-20), or Shamgar's oxgoad victory (v.29)?
tips: Ehud's left-handedness and the concealment of his dagger (v.15-16) show God's unique empowerment for a hidden deliverance
The dramatic detail of the fat closing over the blade (v.19) illustrates how God's plan works through unexpected means
Shamgar's use of an oxgoad (a simple tool) to kill 600 Philistines shows that God's deliverance can come through ordinary people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about the judges?
tips: The judges were temporary, imperfect deliverers who arose in response to Israel's sin
This passage emphasizes that God's deliverance is always active but requires Israel to repent and trust Him
The chapter shows that God uses both powerful and humble individuals (like Ehud) to break cycles of oppression

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The nature of the judges' rule, the concept of 'left-handed' in a military context, or the meaning of 'rest'?
tips: The term 'rest' (shalom) in Judges 3:10 refers to a period of peace after deliverance, not eternal rest
Ehud's left-handedness was significant because it made him less likely to be targeted by the king's guards
The phrase 'the Spirit of the LORD came upon Othniel' (v.4) is a divine empowerment that is not common in the Old Testament context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's deliverance through unexpected means (like Ehud) to your life this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel stuck or oppressed and consider if God might be using an unexpected method to deliver you
Pray for the courage to be like Ehud: to act when no one expects you to (left-handed, hidden)
Surrender a small burden to God, trusting that He will provide a solution through an unexpected channel

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's deliverance through unexpected means, as seen in Ehud's story.
tips: Thank God for the historical examples of His deliverance through ordinary people
Ask for the strength to be a 'left-handed' deliverer in your life
Pray for a sense of rest (shalom) in your current situation through God's intervention

chapters.chapterTitle: Deborah and Barak; Jael Kills Sisera

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 4:4-22 aloud, focusing on the tension between Barak's leadership and Deborah's prophetic role, and the decisive act of Jael.
tips: Note the phrase 'the LORD will draw out Sisera' (v.6) - it shows God's active role
Pay attention to Jael's quiet courage: 'She took him and killed him' (v.21)
Emotional tone shifts from Barak's hesitation to Jael's decisive action

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO does WHAT, WHERE, and WHY for the events of Judges 4.
tips: Deborah summons Barak to lead against Sisera (v.4-5)
Jael kills Sisera after he flees to her tent (v.18-21)
God's victory over Sisera's army (v.14-17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Deborah's prophecy about the woman (v.9), Barak's conditional faith (v.4), or Jael's act (v.21)?
tips: Deborah's prophecy: 'the glory will go to a woman' (v.9) - shows God's sovereignty in unexpected places
Jael's quiet courage: she waits for Sisera to sleep and then kills him with a tent peg (v.21) - an act of decisive faith
The contrast between Barak's initial hesitation and the final victory through a woman

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/editors) trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: To show that God's deliverance comes through unexpected means (a woman) and that true victory requires faith in God's plan
To emphasize that God's power is active in the midst of oppression and that He uses ordinary people (like Jael) for His purposes
To remind Israel that their deliverance is not through their own strength but through God's direct intervention

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of the 'Kenite', why God 'draws out' Sisera, and the significance of the tent peg?
tips: Kenite: a group of people who were allies of Israel (v.17) - Jael is a Kenite, which shows her connection to the broader community
'Draws out Sisera' (v.6) means God will cause Sisera to be defeated by the Israelites - it's a divine strategy
Tent peg: a weapon of war, but here it's used by a woman to kill an enemy - showing that God's victory can come through unconventional means

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of Jael's decisive action in your life this week?
tips: When you face a situation where you feel powerless, ask: 'What is the one small action I can take to bring about God's victory?'
Reflect on a time when you had to act decisively (like Jael) without waiting for permission
This week, identify one obstacle and plan how you can 'drive the peg' (act decisively) to overcome it

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance through unexpected means, and ask for courage to act decisively when needed.
tips: Thank God for using women (like Jael) in His kingdom
Pray for the courage to act when the situation seems hopeless
Ask God to help you see opportunities where He can use you to bring about victory

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 5:1-31 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'O LORD' and the contrast between the enemies' defeat and the land's rest.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'O LORD' (v.2, 4, 6, 13) for emphasis
The phrase 'the stars from heaven' (v.18) shows God's cosmic power
The lament in the last verses (v.27-31) contrasts with the victory

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT God has done, WHERE the victory occurred, and WHY this song was sung.
tips: Deborah and Barak lead the Israelites in battle against the Canaanite kings
Sisera is defeated by Jael, who breaks his skull (v.27-31)
The land experiences peace for 40 years (v.31)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jael's actions (v.27-31), the curse on Meroz (v.29), or the song's refrain (v.1-3)?
tips: Jael's boldness: asking for water and killing Sisera shows God's use of unlikely means
The curse on Meroz for not helping the LORD highlights the cost of disloyalty
The refrain 'O LORD, save us' (v.1, 4) emphasizes continuous trust

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the editors (Samuel) trying to communicate to Israel through this song of victory?
tips: God's victory comes through the weak and the faithful, not the strong or the military
The song reminds Israel that God is the true leader and provider
This passage foreshadows Christ's victory through the cross (the 'unlikely' means)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cosmic warfare imagery, the curse on Meroz, or the role of Sisera's mother?
tips: 'Stars from heaven' (v.18) refers to the heavenly forces of God, not literal stars
Meroz is a place that refused help (v.29) and is cursed to be destroyed
Sisera's mother's wait (v.27) is a tragedy of delayed divine intervention

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's victory through unlikely means to your life this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel like you're in a battle (e.g., with a problem or enemy) and trust God's victory
Practice being like Jael: seek God's help in the small ways (e.g., asking for water) before taking action
Ask God to help you trust in His victory over your 'Sisera' this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's victory through the weak and the importance of community.
tips: Thank God for using unlikely people (like Jael) to defeat the enemy
Pray for courage to be like Deborah and Barak in leading your community
Ask God to help your church (or family) avoid the curse of Meroz by being faithful and helping others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 6:1-23 aloud, focusing on the Angel of the LORD's appearance and Gideon's initial fear.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'The LORD is with you, mighty warrior' (v.13) which reassures Gideon
Pay attention to Gideon's fear and trembling (v.17-18) when he sees the Angel of the LORD
Listen for the contrast between God's promise and Gideon's doubt (v.14-15)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is involved, what happens, where it occurs, and why God is intervening in this story.
tips: Include the oppression of Israel by Midianites for seven years (v.1-6)
Note Gideon's role as a threshing servant (v.11-12) and his initial fear (v.17)
Highlight the Angel of the LORD's appearance and the command to deliver Israel (v.13-17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Angel's promise (v.13), Gideon's request for a sign (v.17-18), or the fleece test (v.17-22)?
tips: The Angel's promise: 'The LORD is with you, mighty warrior' (v.13) reassures Gideon in the midst of fear
Gideon's request for a sign: 'Let me test the LORD' (v.17) shows his need for evidence before acting
The fleece test: The wet/dry fleece (v.17-22) provides a tangible sign of God's presence without violence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the writer (Samuel/editors) trying to communicate to Israel about God's character and their situation?
tips: The passage shows God's faithfulness to deliver Israel from Midianite oppression, just as He delivered them from Egypt (v.6)
It emphasizes that God works through ordinary people (Gideon, a threshing servant) to accomplish His purposes
The story highlights the contrast between God's power and human fear (Gideon's initial hesitation)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand? Consider: the Angel of the LORD's identity, Gideon's fear of death, or the fleece test?
tips: The Angel of the LORD is a preincarnate manifestation of Christ (as in the Old Testament), not a separate being like angels
Gideon's fear of death (v.17-18) is common when facing divine authority, but God promises he will not die
The fleece test (v.17-22) is a practical test that God uses to confirm His presence without requiring violence or large-scale action

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Gideon trusted God to deliver Israel from oppression. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week, even when it seems small or fearsome?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding back from full obedience (like Gideon's initial fear)
Think about something precious you need to surrender to God (like the Baal altar, which represents your own idols of fear)
How can you test God's presence in your life with a simple, visible sign (like the fleece test) this week?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance and ask for courage to trust Him in your fears.
tips: Thank God for His promise: 'The LORD is with you, mighty warrior' (v.13)
Ask for courage to tear down the idols of fear in your life (like G and the Baal altar)
Pray for the Spirit to empower you to be a deliverer in your own situation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 7:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Gideon and God in verses 7-10 and the command to the 300 in verses 17-20.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'too many' (v. 2, 6, 10) which emphasizes God's reduction of forces
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Gideon's fear and obedience in verses 11-13
Note the specific command 'only 300' in verses 17-18

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY God is reducing the army.
tips: Include the testing at the water (v. 6-7)
Note the 300 chosen as the final force (v. 17-18)
Describe the battle strategy: torches, trumpets, and the shout (v. 19-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the water test (v. 6-7), the 300's strategy (v. 17-20), or the Midianite dream (v. 13-14)?
tips: The water test is a powerful test of faith and discernment
The 300's unconventional warfare (torches in jars, trumpets) shows God's wisdom in strategy
The dream of the barley loaf (v. 13) reveals God's sovereign control over the enemy

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/editors) trying to communicate to Israel about God's sovereignty and the nature of victory?
tips: This passage shows that God's victory comes through the few and the weak, not human strength
It emphasizes that Israel must avoid boasting in their own military might
The story foreshadows the cross: God's weakness becomes the instrument of victory

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reduction of forces, the water test, or the unconventional warfare?
tips: The water test (v. 6-7) is a unique method of discernment that requires faith and trust in God's judgment
The term '300' (v. 17) is a specific number that represents God's choice of the few, not a generic number
The battle strategy (v. 19-20) uses terror and confusion to break the enemy, which might seem unconventional but is effective

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of God's reduction of forces to your life this week?
tips: Identify areas where you are overestimating your own abilities and where God might be reducing the problem to a manageable size
Practice trusting God to choose the right people and resources for your situation
Focus on the few key actions that will bring about the victory (like the 300) rather than trying to do everything

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for reducing your burdens and trusting Him to provide the right tools for victory.
tips: Thank God for choosing you (or others) to be part of His work
Ask for courage to trust God's plan when it seems too small
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you follow the strategy of God's few

questions.instruction: Take turns reading Judges 8 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 9:1-60 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Abimelech and the Shechemite lords in verses 1-5 and Jotham's fable in verses 18-21.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'one ruler' (v. 1) and the phrase 'isn't one ruler better than seventy?' (v. 1)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Abimelech's actions: the murder of his brothers (v. 18) and his later death (v. 59)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Abimelech's murder of his brothers (v. 18)
Note the role of Jotham and his fable (v. 18-21)
Describe the outcome: Abimelech's death by a woman (v. 59)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abimelech's initial rule (v. 1-5), Jotham's fable (v. 18-21), or the death by a millstone (v. 59)?
tips: Jotham's fable is a powerful metaphor: the trees seeking a king and the bramble's response
The image of the millstone falling on Abimelech is both violent and symbolic of divine judgment
Abimelech's death by a woman's hand (v. 59) challenges the idea of male dominance and divine retribution

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel about the dangers of usurping power and the consequences of fratricide?
tips: This passage warns against the abuse of power that comes from violence and the lack of divine authority
It shows that God's judgment will come on those who seek power through murder and injustice
The theme of divine retribution is central: the wicked will be destroyed by their own actions

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of fratricide, the role of the 'evil spirit', or the meaning of 'sowing salt'?
tips: Fratricide was a common practice in ancient Near East but here it's portrayed as a grave sin against God
The 'evil spirit' (v. 48) refers to God's judgment on Abimelech's actions, not a demonic entity
Sowing salt (v. 48) means rendering the land barren and unproductive, a way to destroy the city

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge you to avoid the same mistakes as Abimelech in your relationships and leadership?
tips: Consider how you are using power or authority in your lifeâ€”do you have a 'bramble' mentality (selfish, destructive) or a 'productive' one (like the olive tree)?
Pray for the strength to choose leadership with integrity, not by force or violence
This week, practice forgiving others as Abimelech was forgiven by God (v. 59)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His justice and ask for the strength to lead with integrity.
tips: Thank God for delivering us from the tyranny of sin and abuse of power
Pray for courage to confront injustice without violence
Ask God to protect us from the consequences of fratricide in our families and communities

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 10:1-16 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Tola and Jair's rule and the subsequent oppression.
tips: Note the phrase 'Israel did evil' in verse 6
Pay attention to the description of Jair's 30 sons and 30 cities in verse 5
Listen for the emotional tone as God's anger burns (verse 5)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Tola's 23-year rule
Mention Jair's 22-year rule with 30 sons and 30 cities
Note that after Jair, Israel turns to idolatry and is oppressed by Philistines and Ammonites for 18 years

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out most? Consider: Jair's rule (v.5), Israel's sin (v.6), or God's response (v.10-11).
tips: Jair's 30 sons and 30 cities shows the temporary nature of human leadership
The phrase 'Israel did evil' (v.6) is a clear turning point in the story
The call to 'cry to the gods you chose' (v.10) highlights Israel's persistent need for God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Samuel/editors) trying to communicate to Israel about God's response to their sin?
tips: This passage shows that even after a period of God's judges, Israel must return to Him
The key is that when Israel cries to God (after removing foreign gods), He will help
This foreshadows the need for persistent prayer in the face of oppression

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to understand?
tips: Why does God 'sell' Israel to the Philistines and Ammonites? (This is a result of Israel's idolatry)
The phrase 'His soul became impatient' (v.10) refers to God's frustration with Israel's repeated sin
The 18-year oppression by Philistines and Ammonites is a consequence of Israel's sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of persistent prayer (like Israel's cry) this week?
tips: Identify an area where you feel oppressed by sin or circumstances and pray for God's help
Write down what you need to cry to God (like Israel's confession)
Commit to putting away any foreign gods (idols) in your life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Israel's cry for help and God's response.
tips: Thank God for His patience with us even when we sin
Ask for the courage to cry to Him when we feel oppressed
Pray for the strength to put away foreign gods (sin) in our lives

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 13:1-30 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between the angel and Manoah's wife in verses 1-2, and the emotional shift from fear to trust in verses 16-17.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'do not drink wine' (v. 4, 13) and the emphasis on the Nazirite vow (v. 14, 15)
Pay attention to the wife's initial fear (v. 16) and her confident reasoning (v. 17)
Listen for the angel's instructions: 'he will be a Nazirite from the womb' (v. 14) and the spirit beginning to stir (v. 25)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Manoah and his wife, the angel), WHAT (the divine announcement of Samson's birth and Nazirite vow), WHERE (in Israel), and WHY (to deliver Israel from the Philistines).
tips: Include the key event: the angel's visit and the instructions for the Nazirite vow
Note the wife's role as the one who becomes pregnant and the husband's initial fear
Mention the birth of Samson and the spirit beginning to stir

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the angel's declaration that Samson will be a Nazirite from the womb (v. 14), the wife's reasoning (v. 17), or the spirit beginning to stir (v. 25).
tips: The angel's promise of a Nazirite from birth shows God's unique design for Samson's life
The wife's insight that God's plan is safe despite the fear demonstrates trust in divine promises
The spirit beginning to stir (v.25) foreshadows Samson's future strength and purpose

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about the birth of Samson?
tips: This passage emphasizes that God's deliverance for Israel requires a special, anointed leader (Samson) who is set apart from birth
The story shows that God works through ordinary people (a barren couple) to achieve extraordinary purposes
The Nazirite vow highlights that the deliverer must be completely dedicated to God's purposes

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of a Nazirite vow, why God chooses a barren couple, and the role of the angel of the LORD.
tips: A Nazirite vow (from Hebrew 'nazir') involves abstaining from wine, not cutting hair, and dedicating life to God; it's a sign of total commitment
In the context of Judges, God is responding to Israel's repeated failures (v.1-2) by giving a special deliverer through a divine promise
The angel is a theophany (visible manifestation of God) as in the Old Testament, not necessarily Christ in this passage (though the Christ connection is noted)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify one area where you feel called to be set apart for God's purpose, like Samson was from birth. What specific step can you take to begin that dedication?
tips: Start by asking God for a specific way to dedicate your time or talents to His work
Consider how you can avoid the things that would compromise your dedication (e.g., wine, unclean foods)
Reflect on how the spirit of God is beginning to stir in your life (v.25)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of a deliverer when we are in barrenness. Ask for the courage to trust His plan even when it's unclear.
tips: Thank God for the promise of a deliverer when we are in barrenness
Ask for the courage to trust God's plan even when we don't understand
Pray for the spirit to begin stirring in your life to do God's will

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 14:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'from the LORD' (v.1) and the contrast between Samson's parents and the Philistine woman.
tips: Notice the phrase 'from the LORD' (v.1) and the contrast between Israelite and Philistine women
Pay attention to Samson's declaration of the riddle (v.12) and the phrase 'the spirit of the LORD was upon him' (v.14)
The emotional shift from Samson's initial strength (v.14) to his later actions (v.15-16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Samson and his parents, the Philistine woman, the Philistine companions) does WHAT (marry the Philistine woman, face the lion, solve the riddle, kill 30 Philistines) WHERE (in Israel, near Timnah) and WHY (to provoke the Philistines and seek an occasion for God's judgment).
tips: Include Samson's parents' protest and the LORD's plan (v.1-2)
Note the lion attack and honey (v.4-5)
Describe the riddle and its resolution (v.12-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lion attack (v.4-5), the riddle (v.12), or the resolution of the riddle and Samson's revenge (v.15-16)?
tips: Samson's victory over the lion shows God's power in the midst of danger
The riddle is a brilliant test of intelligence that only Samson could solve, highlighting his unique role
The immediate consequence of the riddle being solved: Samson's revenge on the Philistines for their betrayal

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: How does God's plan in Samson's life challenge the idea that we must avoid all foreign influences?
tips: God's people must be faithful and not be influenced by surrounding nations (Philistines) in their marriages
God uses unexpected means (the lion and honey, the riddle) to provide for His purposes
The theme of God's provision through suffering points to Christ's death and resurrection

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify what makes the riddle and Samson's marriage with a Philistine woman challenging to understand in this context.
tips: The Philistine woman was chosen by God to provoke the Philistines, so it's not a random choice but part of God's plan
The riddle is a play on words: the eater (bee) produces honey (sweet) and the strong (lion) is the source of the honey (bee's hive)
In ancient Israel, marriages with foreigners were discouraged, but God used this situation to expose the Philistines' arrogance

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust God to provide for your needs when you face a difficult situation, like Samson who was empowered by the Spirit to overcome the lion?
tips: When you feel overwhelmed, ask God for strength and direction (like Samson's spirit) to face the challenge
Identify a situation where you need to be a 'Samson' â€“ someone who is empowered by God to take action for His purposes
Pray for the courage to be a vessel of God's power in your current circumstances

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about Samson's story: thank God for His provision in your life and ask for strength to be a vessel of His power.
tips: Thank God for the 'honey' (sweetness) that comes from the lion (the suffering) in your life
Ask for the courage to face the challenges that the Philistines represent in your life (opponents) and to use God's strength to overcome
Pray for the wisdom to solve the riddle of life â€“ what do you eat and what do you give up?

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 15:1-30 aloud, focusing on the emotional intensity of Samson's rage and the sudden shift to divine intervention.
tips: Note the phrase 'I will not eat bread until I have killed them' (v.14) for Samson's determination
Observe the contrast between the foxes' torches (v.1-2) and the spring of water (v.20)
Focus on the phrase 'the Spirit of the LORD came mightily' (v.18) as a sign of divine power

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Samson) does WHAT (his vengeance against the Philistines) WHERE (in the Philistine lands) and WHY (because his wife was given to another).
tips: Include Samson's rage leading to the foxes' torches in the grain, vineyards, and olive groves
Note the burning of his wife and father-in-law by the Philistines
Describe how Samson escapes, is bound, and breaks ropes with a donkey's jawbone to kill 1,000 men

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the foxes' torches (v.1-2), the burning of his wife (v.15), or the jawbone (v.18).
tips: The foxes' torches symbolize God's use of the enemy's tools against the enemy (the Philistines) in a way that is both destructive and strategic
The burning of his wife and father-in-law shows the tragic cost of unchecked vengeance
The jawbone is a humble object that becomes a weapon of God's power, illustrating that God works through what seems insignificant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage warns about the danger of vengeance and the need for God's guidance in the face of injustice
It shows that God is the ultimate provider of justice and deliverance, even when the people are in the midst of chaos
The story of Samson's vengeance is a cautionary tale about the consequences of pride and the importance of relying on God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command for vengeance, the role of the Spirit, and the meaning of the jawbone.
tips: The phrase 'the Spirit of the LORD came mightily' (v.18) is a supernatural event that might be confusing to modern readers; it shows God's active presence in the midst of human weakness
The use of a donkey's jawbone as a weapon is unusual; it's a symbol of the underdog and God's power to use what is seemingly insignificant
The burning of Samson's wife and father-in-law by the Philistines is a common practice of vengeance in ancient Near East, but it shows the devastating consequences of Samson's pride

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God's provision in the midst of chaos. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience (like Samson's initial rage)
Think about how God might use a humble tool (like a jawbone) to deliver you from a situation
Practice being still and trusting God to provide when you're in the midst of chaos

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about God's provision in the midst of chaos and the cost of vengeance.
tips: Thank God for providing solutions in the midst of chaos (like the spring in v.20)
Ask for the courage to let go of vengeance and trust God's timing
Pray for the strength to use God's tools (even humble ones) to bring about justice

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 16:1-28 aloud, focusing on the tension between Samson's strength and Delilah's betrayal.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'three times' (v.13, 16, 19) as a pattern of testing
Pay attention to the phrase 'my head is shaved' (v.20) and its immediate consequence
Listen for the shift in tone from Samson's strength to his weakness (v.20) and then to his final victory (v.28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Delilah's role as the woman who betrays Samson for the Philistines
Note the three stages of testing: bowstrings, ropes, hair
Samson's hair grows back after his head is shaved, symbolizing his restored strength

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Delilah's betrayal (v.15-18), Samson's hair being shaved (v.20), or his final collapse of the temple (v.28)?
tips: The moment of Samson's hair being shaved (v.20) shows how his strength is tied to his hair, and the Philistines' deception
The prayer of Samson (v.28) is a powerful example of faith in God even in the face of defeat
The temple collapse (v.28) demonstrates that Samson's victory comes through death and God's power

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that even the strongest of God's people can be betrayed and weakened by enemies
The LORD's departure (v.23) emphasizes that Samson's strength comes from God, not himself
Samson's final victory through death foreshadows Christ's victory through the cross

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Philistines' plan, the meaning of 'shaven head', or the LORD departing?
tips: The phrase 'LORD has departed' (v.23) means God's presence is no longer with Samson, indicating that his strength is temporary
The 'shaven head' (v.20) was a sign of weakness in ancient Israel, as it was associated with the loss of military strength
The Philistines' use of Delilah shows the danger of trusting human wisdom over God's strength

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of Samson's final victory in death to your life this week?
tips: When you feel your strength is gone, remember that God can still work through you
Ask God to help you trust in His timing when you face a crisis
Like Samon, pray for strength in the moment of your greatest need

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of Samson's final victory in death.
tips: Thank God that even in weakness, He can work for our victory
Ask for the courage to face your 'Philistines' (challenges) with faith
Pray for the strength to let go of your 'hair' (self-reliance) and trust in God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 17:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue and the contrast between Micah's actions and his mother's blessing.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I have a Levite as priest' (v.15) as Micah's false confidence
Pay attention to the contradiction in Micah's dedication of the silver to the LORD (v.3-4) by making an idol

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO does WHAT, WHERE, and WHY.
tips: Include the theft of 1,100 pieces of silver from his mother (v.1-2)
Note the creation of a carved image and metal idol for the LORD (v.3-4)
Describe the hiring of a Levite from Bethlehem as priest for 10 pieces of silver per year (v.8-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Micah's false confidence (v.15), the idol dedication (v.3-4), or the hiring of the Levite (v.8-10).
tips: Micah's statement: 'Now I know the LORD will prosper meâ€”I have a Levite as priest' (v.15) shows his transactional view of God
The dedication of the silver to the LORD by making an idol (v.3-4) is a clear example of idolatry
The hiring of the Levite (v.8-10) shows the commercialization of worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the main message from this story?
tips: The author warns that God's blessing cannot be obtained through human systems or transactions
True worship must be without idols and based on genuine relationship with God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What are the challenges in understanding this passage?
tips: Micah's mother cursed him for stealing, but then blessed him by dedicating the silver (v.1-2) - this shows the complexity of blessing and curse
The act of making an idol for the LORD (v.3-4) is a contradiction because the LORD is not to be worshipped with idols
The hiring of a Levite (v.8-10) shows Micah's misunderstanding of the priesthood's role

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can this passage apply to your life?
tips: Avoid creating systems that manipulate God (e.g., rituals, traditions that are not rooted in faith) to get blessings
Seek God in spirit and truth, not in superstition

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 19:1-31 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of the Levite's journey and the violent aftermath.
tips: Notice the phrase 'no king in Israel' (v.1) sets the context of chaos
Pay attention to the contrast between hospitality (v.2-4) and the violent abuse (v.22-25)
The repetition of 'the Levite' (v.2, 12) emphasizes his role as a victim and avenger

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Levite and his concubine) does WHAT (the journey and abuse), WHERE (from Bethlehem to Gibeah), and WHY (the Levite's attempt to reclaim his concubine) happened in Judges 19.
tips: Include the Levite's concubine leaving and returning to her father's house (v.1-4)
Note the journey to Gibeah and the lack of hospitality (v.10-12)
Describe the abuse and the Levite's response: cutting the concubine into twelve pieces (v.22-31)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Levite's decision to cut the concubine (v.22), the city's demand for the Levite (v.20-21), or the Levite's action of sending pieces throughout Israel (v.31)?
tips: The Levite's action of sending the pieces throughout Israel (v.31) is a shocking call to action for the entire nation
The city's demand for the Levite to bring his concubine out (v.20) echoes the Sodom story (Genesis 19) and shows the city's depravity
The phrase 'has such a thing happened since Israel came from Egypt?' (v.31) is a powerful indictment of Israel's moral state

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about their current state of affairs?
tips: Israel had become as corrupt as Sodom, lacking a king and moral leadership
The passage warns that without a king, the people will face violence and moral decay
It points to the need for a new king (the coming of the Messiah) who would restore justice

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The Levite's concubine's role, the city of Gibeah's actions, and the meaning of 'twelve pieces'?
tips: The Levite's concubine was not a wife but a concubine (a female servant) - this was a cultural norm in ancient Israel
Gibeah was a city in Benjamin (a tribe that was part of the Israelite tribes) but it was known for its corruption
The twelve pieces (v.22) symbolize the division of the body to be spread throughout Israel as a warning - the number twelve represents the tribes

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you respond to the violation of hospitality and the call for action in your life this week?
tips: Practice hospitality by inviting someone to your home without conditions
When you see injustice, take a step to address it (like the Levite sending the pieces throughout Israel)
Reflect on how your actions might be causing harm to others and seek reconciliation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of hospitality and the consequences of moral failure in your life.
tips: Ask God to help you be a safe place for others (hospitality)
Pray for courage to confront sin and injustice in your community
Thank God that He provides a way of redemption for a broken world

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Judges 20:1-63 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of the gathering at Mizpah and the escalating violence.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the men of Gibeah' (v.1, 2, 4)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from unity (v.1-3) to the devastating losses (v.22-23)
The phrase 'the LORD says go up' (v.28) carries a heavy weight

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Israel and Benjamin) does WHAT (gathers for war, kills, escapes) WHERE (at Mizpah and Gibeah) and WHY (to purge evil from Gibeah).
tips: The Levite's recount of Gibeah's sin (v.1-4)
Benjamin's refusal and mustering of forces (v.5-14)
The three-day battle and the aftermath (v.21-63)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Levite's account of Gibeah (v.1-4), the three-day battle sequence (v.22-23), or the final destruction of Benjamin (v.51-63)?
tips: The Levite's recount of Gibeah's sin: 'the men of Gibeah were worthless' (v.2) - shows the depth of sin
The phrase 'the LORD says go up' (v.28) - a divine call that Israel must obey
The near extinction of Benjamin: only 600 escape to Rimmon (v.59) - a devastating cost

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/editors trying to communicate to Israel about the nature of sin and the cost of purification?
tips: The passage shows that sin must be purged even when it costs the destruction of a tribe
The LORD's involvement: He directs the battle and provides victory through Israel's obedience
This event foreshadows the need for Christ to bear the cost of sin for the entire community

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The scale of the battle, the role of Benjamin, or the divine strategy?
tips: 'Worthless men' (v.2) - a cultural term for those who have committed grave sin and are unfit to be part of the community
The battle is described in detail (v.22-23) but the exact numbers are hard to interpret (22,000 and 18,000 killed) - this shows the severity of the sin
The phrase 'the LORD says go up' (v.28) - it's a call to action but also a divine judgment that Israel must accept

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of purging sin at great cost to your life this week? Specifically, what area of sin do you need to let go of, even if it costs you?
tips: Consider a relationship or habit that has become a 'Gibeah' - something that is causing harm to the community
Pray for the courage to let go of what is costly to maintain
Surrender a small sin to God, just as Israel surrendered the worthless men of Gibeah

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His judgment on sin and ask for strength to face the cost of purification in your life.
tips: Thank God for the example of the LORD's judgment on sin in the past (as in this chapter) and in Christ
Ask for the courage to face the cost of sin in your life, even if it means sacrifice
Pray for the community to be purified without division, as Israel was united in the battle
